summary: This is a transcript of a voluntary sworn interview conducted by the DOJ Office of the Inspector General (OIG) with a New York City Medical Examiner (Dr. [REDACTED]) regarding the autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein. The interview covers the medical examiner's background, the autopsy findings, the determination of suicide by hanging, and questions about the ligature evidence and scene investigation.

persons.name: Lyeson
persons.context: Primary interviewer from the DOJ Office of the Inspector General, leading the questioning about Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy.

persons.name: Ryan
persons.context: Also present during the interview, asks follow-up questions about the autopsy findings and evidence.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: The witness being interviewed. She conducted Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy on August 11, 2019, and explains her findings, methodology, and conclusion that the death was a suicide by hanging.

persons.name: [REDACTED]
persons.role: General Counsel, NYC Office of Chief Medical Examiner
persons.context: Present during the interview as legal counsel for the medical examiner's office.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the autopsy. The interview is focused on determining the cause and manner of his death in federal custody.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: Another medical examiner at the OCME who was initially assigned to perform Epstein's autopsy but was not working on the day it was conducted.

persons.name: [REDACTED]
persons.context: A photographer who assisted during the autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: [REDACTED]
persons.context: A morgue technician who assisted during the autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Mark Epstein
persons.context: Jeffrey Epstein's brother who hired an independent medical examiner to observe the autopsy.

persons.name: Dr. Michael Bodin
persons.context: A medical examiner hired by Mark Epstein to be present during Jeffrey Epstein's autopsy.

persons.name: [REDACTED]

connections.description: Medical examiner who performed the autopsy on Jeffrey Epstein and determined his cause and manner of death.
Mark Epstein is identified as the brother of Jeffrey Epstein.
Mark Epstein hired Dr. Michael Bodin to be an independent observer during his brother's autopsy.
DOJ/OIG Special Agent interviewing the medical examiner as part of an official investigation.
DOJ/OIG Special Agent-in-Charge participating in the interview and asking follow-up questions.

events.title: Autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] conducts the autopsy of Jeffrey Epstein at the New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner.

events.title: Previous Suicide Attempt by Epstein
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found with a noose around his neck in an apparent previous suicide attempt while in custody.

events.title: DOJ OIG Interview with Medical Examiner
events.description: The DOJ Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary sworn interview with the medical examiner who performed Epstein's autopsy.

locations: New York City Office of the Chief Medical Examiner
Dane County Medical Examiner's Office, Madison, Wisconsin
keyFacts: The medical examiner concluded Jeffrey Epstein's death was a suicide by hanging, citing a ligature furrow, petechial hemorrhages, plethora, and specific fractures of the hyoid bone and thyroid cartilage consistent with hanging.
The examiner noted a lack of defensive wounds, struggle marks, or other trauma that would suggest homicide or an altercation.
There was confusion and inconsistency regarding the ligature (noose) evidence collected from the scene; the examiner expressed doubt that the item presented to her was the actual one used.
Toxicology tests detected no substances in Epstein's system at the time of death.

The medical examiner stated that no one attempted to coerce or bribe her into ruling the death a suicide, though she received unpleasant calls from Epstein's family who were unhappy with the determination.
